defs.docs: # hyper

attributes.value: ! hyper is a **fast** and **correct** HTTP implementation written in and for Rust.
! If just starting out, **check out the [Guides](https://hyper.rs/guides)
! hyper is a lower-level HTTP library, meant to be a building block
! If looking for just a convenient HTTP client, consider the
! The following optional features are available:
! - `runtime` (*enabled by default*): Enables convenient integration with
!   `tokio`, providing connectors and acceptors for TCP, and a default
! - `tcp` (*enabled by default*): Enables convenient implementations over

defs.name: body
defs.docs: Streaming bodies for Requests and Responses

attributes.value: ! Streaming bodies for Requests and Responses
! responses use streaming bodies, instead of complete buffering. This
! allows applications to not use memory they don't need, and allows exerting
! back-pressure on connections by only reading when asked.
! There are two pieces to this in hyper:
!   hyper allows any body type that implements `HttpBody`, allowing
!   applications to have fine-grained control over their streaming.
! - **The [`Body`](Body) concrete type**, which is an implementation of
!   `HttpBody`, and returned by hyper as a "receive stream" (so, for server
!   requests and client responses). It is also a decent default implementation
!   if you don't have very custom needs of your send streams.

defs.name: aggregate
defs.docs: Aggregate the data buffers from a body asynchronously.

attributes.value: / Aggregate the data buffers from a body asynchronously.
/ The returned `impl Buf` groups the `Buf`s from the `HttpBody` without
/ copying them. This is ideal if you don't require a contiguous buffer.

defs.name: is_end_stream
defs.docs: A hint that the `Body` is complete, and doesn't need to be polled more.

attributes.value: / A hint that the `Body` is complete, and doesn't need to be polled more.
/ This can be useful to determine if the there is any body or trailers
/ without having to poll. An empty `Body` could return `true` and hyper
/ would be able to know that only the headers need to be sent. Or, it can
/ also be checked after each `poll_data` call, to allow hyper to try to
/ end the underlying stream with the last chunk, instead of needing to
/ send an extra `DATA` frame just to mark the stream as finished.
/ As a hint, it is used to try to optimize, and thus is OK for a default

defs.name: size_hint
defs.docs: Returns a `SizeHint` providing an upper and lower bound on the possible size.

attributes.value: / Returns a `SizeHint` providing an upper and lower bound on the possible size.
/ If there is an exact size of bytes known, this would allow hyper to
/ send a `Content-Length` header automatically, not needing to fall back to
/ This does not need to be kept updated after polls, it will only be
/ called once to create the headers.

defs.name: client
defs.docs: HTTP Client

attributes.value: ! There are two levels of APIs provided for construct HTTP clients:
! The [`Client`](Client) is the main way to send HTTP requests to a server.
! The default `Client` provides these things on top of the lower-level API:
! - A default **connector**, able to resolve hostnames and connect to
! - A **pool** of existing connections, allowing better performance when
!   making multiple requests to the same hostname.
! - Automatic setting of the `Host` header, based on the request `Uri`.
! - Automatic request **retries** when a pooled connection is closed by the
!   server before any bytes have been written.
! Many of these features can configured, by making use of
! For a small example program simply fetching a URL, take a look at the
! // And then, if the request gets a response...
! // Concatenate the body stream into a single buffer...

defs.name: conn
defs.docs: Lower-level client connection API.

attributes.value: ! The types in this module are to provide a lower-level API based around a
! single connection. Connecting to a host, pooling connections, and the like
! are not handled at this level. This module provides the building blocks to
! If don't have need to manage connections yourself, consider using the

defs.name: send_request
defs.docs: Sends a `Request` on the associated connection.

attributes.value: / Sends a `Request` on the associated connection.
/ Returns a future that if successful, yields the `Response`.
/ There are some key differences in what automatic things the `Client`
/ does for you that will not be done here:
/ - `Client` requires absolute-form `Uri`s, since the scheme and
/   authority are needed to connect. They aren't required here.
/ - Since the `Client` requires absolute-form `Uri`s, it can add
/   the `Host` header based on it. You must add a `Host` header yourself
/ - Since absolute-form `Uri`s are not required, if received, they will
/ # async fn doc(mut tx: SendRequest<Body>) -> hyper::Result<()> {
/ // send it and await a Response

defs.name: into_parts
defs.docs: Return the inner IO object, and additional information.

attributes.value: / Return the inner IO object, and additional information.
/ Only works for HTTP/1 connections. HTTP/2 connections will panic.

defs.name: poll_without_shutdown
defs.docs:
Poll the connection for completion, but without calling `shutdown`
 on the underlying IO.

attributes.value: / Poll the connection for completion, but without calling `shutdown`
/ This is useful to allow running a connection while doing an HTTP
/ upgrade. Once the upgrade is completed, the connection would be "done",
/ but it is not desired to actually shutdown the IO object. Instead you
/ to work with this function; or use the `without_shutdown` wrapper.

defs.name: without_shutdown
defs.docs:
Prevent shutdown of the underlying IO object at the end of service the request,
 instead run `into_parts`. This is a convenience wrapper over `poll_without_shutdown`.

attributes.value: / Prevent shutdown of the underlying IO object at the end of service the request,
/ instead run `into_parts`. This is a convenience wrapper over `poll_without_shutdown`.

defs.name: http2_keep_alive_timeout
defs.docs: Sets a timeout for receiving an acknowledgement of the keep-alive ping.

attributes.value: / Sets a timeout for receiving an acknowledgement of the keep-alive ping.
/ If the ping is not acknowledged within the timeout, the connection will
/ be closed. Does nothing if `http2_keep_alive_interval` is disabled.
/ Requires the `runtime` cargo feature to be enabled.

defs.name: http2_keep_alive_while_idle
defs.docs: Sets whether HTTP2 keep-alive should apply while the connection is idle.

attributes.value: / Sets whether HTTP2 keep-alive should apply while the connection is idle.
/ If disabled, keep-alive pings are only sent while there are open
/ request/responses streams. If enabled, pings are also sent when no
/ streams are active. Does nothing if `http2_keep_alive_interval` is
/ Requires the `runtime` cargo feature to be enabled.

/ Sets the [`HttpInfo`](HttpInfo) value on responses, which includes
/ transport information such as the remote socket address used.

defs.name: http1_writev
defs.docs:
Set whether HTTP/1 connections should try to use vectored writes,
 or always flatten into a single buffer.

attributes.value: / Set whether HTTP/1 connections should try to use vectored writes,
/ or always flatten into a single buffer.
/ Note that setting this to false may mean more copies of body data,
/ but may also improve performance when an IO transport doesn't
/ support vectored writes well, such as most TLS implementations.

defs.name: http1_read_buf_exact_size
defs.docs: Sets the exact size of the read buffer to *always* use.

attributes.value: / Sets the exact size of the read buffer to *always* use.
/ Note that setting this option unsets the `http1_max_buf_size` option.
/ Default is an adaptive read buffer.

defs.name: http1_max_buf_size
defs.docs: Set the maximum buffer size for the connection.

attributes.value: / Set the maximum buffer size for the connection.
/ Note that setting this option unsets the `http1_read_exact_buf_size` option.
/ The minimum value allowed is 8192. This method panics if the passed `max` is less than the minimum.

/ Note that this setting does not affect HTTP/2.

/ Note that setting this to true prevents HTTP/1 from being allowed.

/ If disabled, keep-alive pings are only sent while there are open
/ request/responses streams. If enabled, pings are also sent when no
/ streams are active. Does nothing if `http2_keep_alive_interval` is
/ Requires the `runtime` cargo feature to be enabled.

/ This means a request that is queued, and gets given an idle, reused

attributes.value: / Set whether HTTP/1 connections should support half-closures.
/ Clients can chose to shutdown their write-side while waiting
/ for the server to respond. Setting this to `true` will
/ prevent closing the connection immediately if `read`
/ detects an EOF in the middle of a request.

attributes.value: / Set whether HTTP/1 connections should try to use vectored writes,
/ or always flatten into a single buffer.
/ Note that setting this to false may mean more copies of body data,
/ but may also improve performance when an IO transport doesn't
/ support vectored writes well, such as most TLS implementations.

defs.name: into_parts

attributes.value: / Return the inner IO object, and additional information.
/ If the IO object has been "rewound" the io will not contain those bytes rewound.

/ that the connection is "done". Otherwise, it may not have finished
/ This method will panic if this connection is using an h2 protocol.

defs.name: poll_without_shutdown
defs.docs:
Poll the connection for completion, but without calling `shutdown`
 on the underlying IO.

attributes.value: / Poll the connection for completion, but without calling `shutdown`
/ This is useful to allow running a connection while doing an HTTP
/ upgrade. Once the upgrade is completed, the connection would be "done",
/ but it is not desired to actually shutdown the IO object. Instead you
/ to work with this function; or use the `without_shutdown` wrapper.

defs.name: without_shutdown
defs.docs:
Prevent shutdown of the underlying IO object at the end of service the request,
 instead run `into_parts`. This is a convenience wrapper over `poll_without_shutdown`.

attributes.value: / Prevent shutdown of the underlying IO object at the end of service the request,
/ instead run `into_parts`. This is a convenience wrapper over `poll_without_shutdown`.

defs.name: set_nodelay
defs.docs: Set the value of `TCP_NODELAY` option for accepted connections.

attributes.value: / Set the value of `TCP_NODELAY` option for accepted connections.

defs.name: set_sleep_on_errors
defs.docs: Set whether to sleep on accept errors.

attributes.value: / Set whether to sleep on accept errors.
/ A possible scenario is that the process has hit the max open files
/ allowed, and so trying to accept a new connection will fail with
/ `EMFILE`. In some cases, it's preferable to just wait for some time, if
/ the application will likely close some files (or connections), and try
/ to accept the connection again. If this option is `true`, the error
/ will be logged at the `error` level, since it is still a big deal,
/ and then the listener will sleep for 1 second.
/ In other cases, hitting the max open files should be treat similarly
/ to being out-of-memory, and simply error (and shutdown). Setting
/ this option to `false` will allow that.

/ option to false will allow that.

defs.name: service
defs.docs: Asynchronous Services

attributes.value: ! A [`Service`](Service) is a trait representing an asynchronous
! function of a request to a response. It's similar to
! The argument and return value isn't strictly required to be for HTTP.
! Therefore, hyper uses several "trait aliases" to reduce clutter around
! - `HttpService`: This is blanketly implemented for all types that
! - `MakeService`: When a `Service` returns a new `Service` as its "response",
!   we consider it a `MakeService`. Again, blanketly implemented in those cases.
! - `MakeConnection`: A `Service` that returns a "connection", a type that
! In hyper, especially in the server setting, a `Service` is usually bound
! to a single connection. It defines how to respond to **all** requests that
! While it's possible to implement `Service` for a type manually, the helper
! [`service_fn`](service_fn) should be sufficient for most cases.
! Since a `Service` is bound to a single connection, a [`Server`](crate::Server)
! needs a way to make them as it accepts connections. This is what a
! Resources that need to be shared by all `Service`s can be put into a
! `MakeService`, and then passed to individual `Service`s when `call`

defs.name: read_buf
defs.docs: A buffer of bytes that have been read but not processed as HTTP.

attributes.value: / A buffer of bytes that have been read but not processed as HTTP.
/ For instance, if the `Connection` is used for an HTTP upgrade request,
/ it is possible the server sent back the first bytes of the new protocol
/ You will want to check for any existing bytes if you plan to continue

defs.name: downcast
defs.docs: Tries to downcast the internal trait object to the type passed.
